conclusion: To find the effective value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, we need to follow these steps.
The coil is a square with side length L.
The area A of the coil is A = L^2.
The coil rotates at a constant angular velocity ω.
The magnetic flux Φ through the coil is given by Φ = B · A · cos(θ).
The induced EMF 𝓔 is given by Faraday's Law: 𝓔 = -N dΦ/dt.
The angle θ changes with time as θ = ωt, so Φ = B · L^2 · cos(ωt).
Differentiating Φ with respect to time t gives dΦ/dt = -B · L^2 · ω · sin(ωt).
Substituting into Faraday's Law gives 𝓔 = N · B · L^2 · ω · sin(ωt).
The effective (RMS) value of the induced EMF is given by 𝓔_rms = 𝓔_max/√2.
The maximum induced EMF occurs when sin(ωt) = 1, so 𝓔_max = N · B · L^2 · ω.
The RMS value is 𝓔_rms = N · B · L^2 · ω/√2.
The effective value of the induced electromotive force in the coil is 𝓔_rms = N · B · L^2 · ω/√2.
